Kicks the door in frustration but then turns to leave, showing a limit to persistence.
Walks alone down a country road in the rain, coughing and exhausted, showing physical and emotional struggle without clear coping strategy.
Approaches Sandra's cottage despite her emotional and physical state, and attempts to mask her distress by putting on a brave face.
Tries to enter Sandra's home saying she just wanted to visit but quickly offers to leave, displaying social awkwardness or insecurity.
Giggles and engages in nervous, friendly chatter; appreciates Sandra's hospitality and does not rush to leave.
Expresses thoughtful, optimistic view of clouds and childhood memories, showing a sincere and good-natured perspective.
Smiles awkwardly and declines Sandra's offer to let out anger, showing reluctance to express herself openly.
Eventually accepts to join Sandra in drinking wine after initial hesitation, showing some openness to companionship.
Declines Sandra's invitation to pursue an actual career as an artist, smiling awkwardly and dismissing the idea as too fancy.
Avoids expressing anger or engaging in emotional release when encouraged by Sandra, showing reluctance to confront or express feelings openly.
Admits to missing someone despite their flaws, expresses vulnerability while drunk.
Behaves drunkenly and leaves abruptly, showing limited social grace in the moment.
Expresses contradictory feelings about her partner, showing emotional confusion while drunk.
Admits she needs to go to bed because she feels physically unwell from drinking.
Engages in playful teasing and laughter with Everett, showing openness and shared humor.
Acknowledges and affirms her commitment and affection towards Everett sincerely.
Initiates playful and imaginative interaction by asking Everett to see more in the clouds, demonstrating confidence in her perspective and engaging others thoughtfully.
Lightheartedly challenges Everett's view and maintains control of the conversation, showing social skill and emotional intelligence.
Relies on Everett’s assurances emotionally without asserting strong personal agency or decisive planning about her situation.
Confronts Everett about the unknown destination, asks direct questions to understand the situation.
Shows confusion and disbelief upon learning about her daughter and the woman's whereabouts, but proceeds to face the situation by walking toward the house.
Does not assertively engage with Kay or Paul upon seeing them; instead, she quietly walks past, seeming uncertain.
Shares a quiet moment eating raspberries simultaneously with Kay from opposite sides of a fence, smiles watching her.
Does not engage directly with Kay, walks past the house without looking back after the shared moment.
Smiles warmly at Everett, who smiles back.
Jokes lightly with the doctor about giving up smoking, smiles.
Studies a young woman discreetly and smiles observing her without confrontation.
Notices and removes a pebble from her boot to continue comfortably on her way.
Shares a quiet, momentary connection with Kay by eating raspberries simultaneously but does not engage further.
Chooses to walk past the house without looking back, showing controlled restraint and confidence.
Discusses her health issues openly and with some humor, showing awareness but limited action for improvement.
Smiles despite health difficulties, tries to be pleasant to Everett.
Invites Everett to sit by her when she is tired.
Suggests Everett get more dogs to not be lonely.
Does not complain openly about her deteriorating health, shows patience.
Gathers unsold paintings despite feeling tired and laboured breathing.
Attempts to go upstairs but cannot hoist herself up, sits down instead.
Responds calmly to Everett's frustration and requests him to sit by her.
Is becoming too tired and ill to paint as much as before, resulting in fewer paintings and sales.
Gives a painting to Kay freely, refuses to accept payment, and smiles warmly during the interaction.
Watches Kay closely as she leaves, showing a caring and attentive attitude.
Does not engage much in general conversation but shows kindness in actions.
Suddenly bursts into tears alone, indicating internal emotional pain rather than direct warmth or coldness toward others.
Watches Kay carefully as she admires her paintings and approaches her with the painting of the girl in the pink dress, showing attentiveness and awareness.
Offers the painting to Kay freely and quietly insists she take it, showing generosity but perhaps also lack of assertiveness or negotiation skill.
Smiles but is unable to think of what to say when Kay compliments her paintings, indicating some social difficulty or lack of confidence in interpersonal communication.
Discreetly tries to keep an eye on Kay as she leaves, displaying vigilance and emotional investment.
Suddenly bursts into tears and lets herself cry over her unfinished painting, showing emotional vulnerability but possibly a momentary loss of control affecting her ability to work capably.
Wipes away tears and starts to fix her ruined painting
Speaks gently and appreciatively when Everett arranges the day bed ('That's lovely. Lovely.')
Self-deprecating humor about becoming a housemaid ('Some housemaid I became.')
Wipes away her tears and starts to fix her ruined painting.
Wipes paint off her face and shirt with an old wet rag.
Hoists herself out of the chair and attempts to climb a ladder, resulting in a fall.
Sits thoughtfully painting from her bed despite being slower and less joyful.
Struggles with physical frailty and limited responsiveness towards the end of the excerpt.
Reaches out to touch Everett, wraps her hand around his hand despite her weakness, expresses a wish to be better at looking after him.
Tries to speak despite weakness and illness.
Expresses a wish to be better at looking after Everett, acknowledging her own limitations.
Pulls Everett closer, expresses understanding and love despite lack of material things, uses affectionate terms.
